bug.author: dsmilkov
bug.summary: Failing tests in core regarding local storage
bug.description:
See this <denchmark-link:https://api.travis-ci.org/v3/job/387154917/log.txt>log</denchmark-link> (search for ) for the test that's failing. The relevant snippet is: <denchmark-code>Firefox 60.0.0 (Mac OS X 10.12.0) ModelManagement {"BACKEND":"test-cpu"} List models: 1 result FAILEDï¿½[39m Expected 2 to equal 1. <Jasmine> @src/io/model_management_test.ts:110:16 <- src/io/model_management_test.js:149:29 </denchmark-code>
It consistently fails on Travis on Firefox on Mac OS X 10.12.0 as of couple days ago.

comments.comment: Here is <denchmark-link:https://travis-ci.org/tensorflow/tfjs-core/jobs/386952306#L4134>another log</denchmark-link> from another run. Which exact test fails is flaky since the failure depends on the order of execution.

See this <denchmark-link:https://github.com/tensorflow/tfjs-core/pull/1075>PR's</denchmark-link> description for context. tl;dr when we switched from karma 2.x to 3.x, by default tests run in random order and localstorage tests were not isolated properly. Switching back to non-random order will fix this issue, but nevertheless, it would be good to fix those tests.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/dsmilkov>@dsmilkov</denchmark-link> That's good info. However, I don't see how random order by itself may affect the test results. The tests are written in a way that doesn't depend on the order in which the individual s are executed. Is it possible that the tests are executing ? That would explain some of the random failures we have been seeing regarding local storage.
Chatted offline. I'm fairly certain that tests run sequentially, so I think it's related to not properly cleaning up the local database.
Pretty sure we don't have tests failing at head now, closing this out.
